abstract.p: Background. Surgical telementoring has been reported for decades. However, there exists limited evidence of clinical outcome and educational benefits. Objective. To perform a comprehensive review of surgical telementoring surveys published in the past 2 decades. Results. Of 624 primary identified articles, 34 articles were reviewed. A total of 433 surgical procedures were performed by 180 surgeons. Most common telementored procedures were laparoscopic cholecystectomy (57 cases, 13%), endovascular treatment of aortic aneurysm (48 cases, 11%), laparoscopic colectomy (32 cases, 7%), and nefrectomies (41 cases, 9%). In all, 167 (38%) cases had a laparoscopic approach, and 8 cases (5%) were converted to open surgery. Overall, 20 complications (5%) were reported (liver bleeding, trocar port bleeding, bile collection, postoperative ileus, wound infection, serosa tears, iliac artery rupture, conversion open surgery). Eight surveys (23%) have structured assessment of educational outcomes. Telementoring was combined with simulators (n = 2) and robotics (n = 3). Twelve surveys (35%) were intercontinental. Technology satisfaction was high among 83% of surgeons. Conclusion. Few surveys have a structured assessment of educational outcome. Telementoring has improved impact on surgical education. Reported complication rate was 5%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Surgical telementoring by videoconference was first described in the 1960s,1,2 when Dr Michael Ellis DeBakey pioneered the field of telemedicine with the first videoconference demonstration of open heart surgery to be transmitted overseas by satellite. Reported results of mentoring are improved surgical practice, education, treatment, and postoperative care,3,4 and telementoring is described as a natural fit in surgery.5 Solutions have been demonstrated for laparoscopic surgery6-8 and in combination with robotic surgery.9-11 Furthermore, videoconferencing has gained increasing popularity in all fields of medicine, especially in education of medical personnel.12-15

Surgeons are often sparsely geographically distributed, and with a predicted shortage of surgeons,16 distance education might become increasingly important. Recent developments in information technology have led to a renewed interest in the potential of telemedicine to provide new collaborative solutions. Recently, a national US research initiative was launched. The American Medical Foundation for Peer Review and Education has brought together several specialty surgical societies to determine whether telementoring is an effective way for physicians to learn new skills and improve old ones.17

However, little attention has been paid to the educational and clinical benefits of telemedicine. One criticism of the literature on surgical telementoring is that studies to date have tended to focus on the first level of technology development (piloting),18 disregarding assessment of clinical and educational outcomes. Several studies have attempted to provide evidence for cost-effectiveness19-21 and safety22-24 of telementoring systems, but there are insufficient data about clinical and educational outcomes. The main objectives of this article are to summarize clinical and educational outcomes of surgical telementoring, to estimate complication rate (operative and postoperative), and to infer future direction of surgical telementoring research.

sec.title: Search Strategy and Data Collection
sec.p: The review was performed according to the PRISMA statement.25,26 Main sources were PubMed, Association of Computing Machinery (ACM), and Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE Xplore) databases (1990-2010). After discussion among coauthors, the following combination of search terms was applied: Surgery, Surgical, Telementoring, Telesurgical, Teleconsultation, Laparoscopic, Videoconference. Inclusion criteria were

list-item.p: Clinical surveys defined as: Assessment of morbidity, mortality, conversion rate, complications, operation time, and length of stay.
Educational surveys defined as: Assessment of surgical education with focus on learning curve, trainee satisfaction, and skills improvement.
Technical surveys defined as: Technical challenges of telementoring, such as bandwidth, video encoding, resolution, and delay of voice and picture.

sec.p: Surgeons (KMA and ROL) and information and communication technology professionals (JGB and TC) examined aspects in their respective expertise group and agreed on inclusion. First, we did a full text search and second, we used title and abstract to identify relevant articles. Finally, we searched reference lists of articles included. Articles that were clearly unrelated to the topic, duplicates, editorials, review articles, letters or comments, and single case reports were excluded. For those articles possibly fulfilling the inclusion criteria, full text were retrieved and assessed for eligibility. Areas of disagreement were discussed and a decision was based on either majority or new consensus (Figure 1). To clarify numbers of telementored cases and technical issues, corresponding authors were e-mailed. Data were extracted to a standard electronic format (Excel 2007, Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA).

sec.title: Statistics and Study Quality Assessment
sec.p: Studies were scored by the following criteria: research question specified; classification of trial (randomized, case–control, prospective observational); outcome type (clinical, technical, and educational); clinical (complications, surgical procedures, mortality, morbidity); and educational assessment (assessment tools, usefulness, improved skills). Descriptive statistics were performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 624 articles were identified (PubMed, 363; ACM, 118; IEEE Explore, 143); 34 articles were included in the final review9,23,24,27-57 (Figure 1).

sec.title: Study Characteristics
sec.p: There was an increasing trend of annual publications. Forty-seven percent (16) of studies were located in the United States, followed by Europe with 35% (12) and Canada with 15% (5; Table 1). Surveys were classified as clinical (19), technical (15), or educational (8); 8 trials had a combination of categories. Three studies had a randomized design,40,43,53 and the remaining studies had an observational or case–case control design.

sec.title: Clinical Aspects
sec.p: Overall, 433 surgical procedures were performed by 180 surgeons. Complication rate was 5%. Eleven surgical specialties were represented. The most common telementored procedures were laparoscopic cholecystectomy (57 cases, 13%), endovascular treatment of aortic aneurysm (48 cases, 11%), laparoscopic colectomy (32 cases, 7%), and nephrectomy (41 cases, 9%). In all, 167 (38%) cases had a laparoscopic approach, and 8 cases (5%) were converted to open surgery. Overall, 20 complications (4.6%) were reported (liver bleeding, trocar port bleeding, bile collection, postoperative ileus, wound infection, serosa tears, iliac artery rupture, conversion to open surgery; Table 2).

sec.title: Educational Aspects
sec.p: Eight surveys (23%) have educational assessment as primary outcome.35,37,40,43,44,52,53 Two studies mentor medical students (n = 63), 2 surveys general surgeons (n = 53), and 3 surveys surgical residents (n = 24). Surgical performance was evaluated by recognition of anatomical landmarks, “Global Operative Assessment of Laparoscopic Skills,” measurement of task performance (grasping, cutting, clip applying, suturing, economy of movement). All surveys report an expert–novice mentor situation. Two surveys included simulation, and 3 surveys included robotics (remote camera control or grasper). All surveys report a positive outcome of telementoring on surgical performance (Table 3).

sec.title: Technical Aspects
sec.p: Twelve studies (35%) report specific measurements of video transmission delay, only 8 solutions to provide a delay within an acceptable range (one-way, 250 ms; two-ways, 500 ms). Most studies (58%) used commercial solutions, but in-house developed (14%) and freeware solutions (6%) were also reported (Table 4).

sec.title: Findings Summary
sec.p: Present understanding of the effects of videoconference technology on surgical practice is limited. This review is the first comprehensive review of surgical telementoring, including 34 surveys performed over the past 20 years. In all, 433 surgical procedures were reported, with a complication frequency of 5%. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, colectomy, and endovascular treatment of aortic aneurysm were the most common procedures. All surveys focus on education; however, only 8 surveys (23%) have a systematic evaluation of surgical performance and educational outcome. All surveys report improved surgical performance. Perceived usefulness of surgical telementoring was high among 83% of surgical trainees. There is considerable room for improvement of research quality, as only 20% of articles had defined a clear research question. Similarly, only 30% of surveys performed an evaluation of user satisfaction of the technological telementor solution.

sec.title: Clinical Aspects
sec.p: Recently, a meta-analysis supports evidence that trainees can obtain similar clinical results to expert surgeons in laparoscopic colorectal surgery if supervised by an experienced trainer.4 Two surveys of laparascopic telementoring48,50 were included in this review, showing no significant difference in conversion, anastomotic leak, or mortality compared with onsite mentoring. Similar results were also shown by Panait et al.43 In our review, there is a 5% overall complication rate and 5% conversion rate, which is in accordance with other surveys.4 One study reports decreased operation time of telementoring37 compared with physical presence. In contrast, the surveys by Schlachta et al47,48 revealed an increased operating time, but a significant decrease in hospital days. Most studies were not randomized, which makes it difficult to estimate significance of the survey. There is no evidence in included studies of increased cost-effectiveness of surgical telementoring, for instance, reduced transfers between hospitals or other terms of resource utilization.

sec.title: Surgeon’s Workforce and Education
sec.p: Unless the rate at which general surgeons are trained increases, the number of general surgeons per population will continue to decline.58 Because of an expanding/aging population, there will be a 31% increase in surgical work between 2001 and 2020.59,60 Williams et al16 estimated that there will be a 9% shortage (in 2030) in the surgical workforce, with greater shortages in some subspecialties. This means that the rate and volume of surgical education has to increase, videoconference and telementoring can be used to meet this demand. Telementoring as a tool for education between different levels of health care has been described by different surgical specialties.61,62 Demartines et al63,64 assessed telemedicine in surgical education and patient care. Participant satisfaction was high and the opportunity to discuss case management significantly improved. However, bringing together multiple experts to focus on a single patient is a logistical challenge. With videoconferencing and telementoring, discussion of a series of patients among a broad range of experts is possible across vast distances. Kunkler et al65 performed a trial where multidisciplinary team meetings by videoconferencing was found to be cost-effective and breast cancer multidisciplinary teams have similar clinical effectiveness to standard “in-person” meetings

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: One limitation in search for relevant literature is lack of standardized terminology. A reasonable explanation for conflicting terminology could be that telemedicine and e-health are relatively new fields. For example, we had to use both “telementoring” and “videoconferencing” in order to not miss out on relevant surveys. There is room for improvement of research quality; 7 surveys (20%) had a well-formulated research question, but only 3 surveys had some form of randomization of allocation. Another drawback in this review is publication bias for successful telementoring projects. Most of the sampled studies had positive outcomes and yet it is generally known that there are challenges encountered with implementing telementoring solutions in clinical settings.

sec.title: User and Mentor Aspects
sec.p: One major aspect in achieving adoption of new technology is the experience of the mentors and trainees. Our review shows that evidence of user acceptance of current technology is lacking. Some studies focus on the mentors and trainees satisfaction with the technological solution used for telementoring.37,40,43,51-53 As only Schneider et al51 report on resolution of video, no evidence from systematic studies therefore exists on what picture resolution is required to achieve high-perceived video resolution quality among mentors and trainees. In the evaluation of perceived audio quality, 60% of the studies report high perceived quality. Another important user aspect is experienced delay. Few studies (35%) report measured delay and very few report on how the delay was measured (both ways vs only one way). We used an acceptance criterion of 250 ms one way and 500 ms both ways, based on our experience with videoconferencing.

sec.title: Technological Aspects
sec.p: From a clinical perspective, aspects such as video encoding and video resolution in telementoring solutions are important. Video encoding affects, for instance, how nuances in color of the intestines get represented in the video signal. Picture resolution affects what anatomical landmarks may be identified with a high degree of certainty. It is therefore surprising that these 2 aspects are the least reported; only 3 studies report the video resolution used and at the same time provide an evaluation of perceived picture quality. A video resolution of 768 × 492 and higher is perceived to give high perceived video quality, whereas 320 × 240 and lower is evaluated to provide medium perceived picture quality. The most reported technical feature is telestration (44%) and it seems that this feature is mandatory for all telementoring solutions.

sec.title: Future Technology Perspectives
sec.p: The current focus on mobile devices as cell phones and tablet PCs (eg, iPad) opens up a new dimension. There has been renewed interest in mobile telemedicine solutions owing to new and emerging mobile technology such as third and fourth generation of mobile device communication (3G and 4G), increased usability of mobile phones, and Internet-enabled mobile devices.

Videoconferencing as a clinical tool has been used in multiple settings during the past decades18; however, most of these systems have been stationary units. A mobile videoconference solution will bring new and important aspects to this technology, as surgeons can easily transport and use the system in multiple settings. We believe that mobile videoconference solutions based on tablet PC technology have a potential to positively influence surgical practice, but further research is needed.

sec.title: Future Telementor Research
sec.p: Most studies included in this review were classified as system installation and were designed as prospective observational surveys. However, technological barriers of videoconferencing have been substantially reduced and high-quality commercial solutions for telementoring and videoconferencing are easy accessible. There is therefore less need for surveys focusing on technical aspects. In our opinion, future telementor trials must focus on the following:

list-item.p: Education of surgeons: There is a huge demand in society for new surgeons. How can videoconferencing and telementoring contribute to a more cost-effective education?
Clinical aspects: Is telementoring a safe method to educate new or inexperienced surgeons or does complication rates increase when surgical education is not performed hands on?
Telementoring in combination with emerging technology: How can telementoring be combined with simulators, robotics, and mobile platforms for educational and clinical purposes?

Licensure and liability problems: Telementoring are often performed across organizational borders. Expert surgeons at university hospitals usually have an extremely tight schedule with no extra time to mentor surgeons at a local hospital. How shall organizational issues such as licensure, credentialing, hospital finances, legal matters, and potential malpractice be dealt with?

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Telementoring is well suited to overcome geographical barriers and is suitable for surgical training and education. Technological barriers of surgical telementoring have decreased during recent years, and high-quality videoconference equipment is accessible on a commercial basis. However, implementation of telemedicine and videoconference is slower than expected within the surgical community. Our review shows similar complication and conversion rates of surgical telementoring when compared with onsite mentoring. To meet the increasing demand for general surgeons, surgical telementoring for educational purposes should be further explored and evaluated. New surgical telementor surveys should have a clearly defined research objective, assessing clinical and educational aspects in a systematic manner.
